titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Village of Jamaica, Queens County temperance collection 1977.600
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-17T11:15-0500

did.unittitle: Village of Jamaica, Queens County temperance collection
did.abstract: This collection consists of the meeting minutes and constitution of the Temperance Society of School District No. 4 in the Village of Jamaica, Queens County, dating from 1833, and a petition to the Board of Trustees of the Village of Jamaica from its residents requesting an increase in the number of police officers to combat the problems of "intemperance and profanity," dated 1855.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: School District Temperance Society No. 4 (Jamaica, New York, N.Y.).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Village of Jamaica, Queens County temperance collection, 1977.600, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
